name: 2-(1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl)-3-phenylquinoxaline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3221
Reason: 2-(1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl)-3-phenylquinoxaline has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is naphthalene, which has a melting point of -10.5°C. The presence of two phenyl groups increases the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, approximately +20°C each. The 1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl group introduces a rigid structure with a melting point contribution of approximately +10°C. The quinoxaline ring itself can also contribute to the melting point due to its planarity and ability to form hydrogen bonds, estimated at around +20°C. The ketone group introduces a polar carbonyl interaction, which can raise the melting point by approximately +30°C. The methyl group can also contribute to the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5°C.
